description: The latest entry in the Sakura series is more action-packed than ever before! Sakura Clickers is a fast-paced, exciting adventure, full of content, in which you defeat your foes with the power of your mouse!
minimum_requirements: OS: Microsoft Windows XP/Vista/7/8 (32 bit or 64 bit) Processor: 1Ghz Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: DirectX® 9 Compatible Graphics Card DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 200 MB available space

Yes. I'm a female gamer. Yes, I am completely straight. Yes I enjoy this game.  You might be thinking 'bah, girl gamers! They just like casual crap' - but if you look at my steam profile you'll see I have hundreds of hours game time in MANY games - from casual to rpg to MANY others.  But about this game - yes, all the characters are females in relatively revealing clothing, and yes their cries when they're hit are suggestive. Personally, I do turn off the voices - It's not that I think it's bad, or even 'inappropriate' - I just don't need it.  I actually REALLY like the designs of the characters - what's wrong with being a good looking woman in sexy clothing?  'But they're just ♥♥♥♥s! They're asking for it!' no.. no they're not.. that's a VERY sexist way of thinking. For many women, feeling 'sexy' is actually empowering and shows that she has CONFIDENCE in herself. It's how they BEHAVE that determines a '♥♥♥♥'. But that's a whole nother discussion for another time.  The art is beautiful and very well done, and I love the new backgrounds that are changing as you go up in the realms.  This is a good clicker game, and I see updates are going on to help improve and balance the gameplay. I really appreciate that. It shows the creator really gives a damn.  The only thing I could possibly say is one downfall for me? I'd love it if there were some sexy bishounen male characters that would pop up from time to time. Yes, the main target audience for this game IS men - but there will be girls who play too. And if men think that they're allowed to oggle hot women, they shouldn't be uncomfortable with women oggling hot men too!

I don't usually play weeaboo/ecchi type games but I was bored and this caught my eye. Okay, so the boobs caught my eye. And I started playing the game just to see anime girl boobs. But I kept playing for the actualy gameplay.  The concept is simple: you click to collect gold, you upgrade your characters, and you keep doing that. But wow. I'm surprised at how many characters there are, both monsters and allies. You can also go up to an extremely high number of gold. Eventually, you can 'rebirth'. Which you basically just start over with special currency that you can use to permanately upgrade yourself/allies.  A lot of people in the reviews said they just leave their game sitting there. All this does is allow you to collect gold. The bosses will be too tough to beat if you don't upgrade your characters. Leaving your game to farm gold does help, but it's a slow process unless you have done a lot of upgrading.  About the nude mod: it sucks. Don't play this game just to install it. I actually preffered the girls with their clothes on.  I absolutely recommend this game. I thought I would hate it but am now pretty addicted to it.

Some folks are going to hate on this because I like this game Unironicly. No, I don't consider this a Hentai game. This is a hentai game in about the same way that the moon is made of cheese. From a distance, someone uneducated could percieve it to be true, but it's just not. At most it's Ecchi, but the scantily clad anime women don't actually undress, pose in any manner that is remotely provocative, or try to make romantic advances on the player.   The moaning and whining sounds risque at best, but you'd have to be severely innocent to be able to get an honest fap out of this game. Yes, the game does move at a slow crawl, but it's an idle game. It plays it's damn self when you close it, and then you come back to it. And you do other things. Nothing terribly new here. Some folks complain about a lack of monster variety, but I'm guessing they only played a few minutes, and never got to higher levels where things like dragon girls, harpies, and bunny girls start to show up.   Perhaps the pacing for revealing new monster types is too slow for folks? It's meant to be slow. Found it fun to play while doing a lot of other things, which I am pretty sure is the intent. The different moans, while amusing, do run a bit old after a while.   Thankfully there are options to silence everything if you want to. There are in game purchases, but they don't in any way affect the gameplay, which actually strikes me as a very honest free to play model. Buying outfits is not to enhance the gameplay: it's strictly there to support the developer, and you don't have to do it to enjoy pretty much everything the game really offers you.  I'll probably unlock everything on this game over a period of a month or two, like with Clicker hero, before I get bored of it.  The game may also have interesting updates in the future. We'll see.  Also, by all accounts, better than Gone Home.

Many people will ridicule this game for being what it is, but I truly believe that this game is an amazing experience and everyone should play it. One of the parts of this game I really enjoyed was the story. There was no clear story ever presented in game, but because of this I was able to use my imagination to create the explanation of why I was fighting a seemingly endless horde of monsters in the middle of the desert. Another thing I really liked about this game was the character customization. While I couldn't figure out how to change my gender, I was greeted with plenty of other customization options such as changing my outfit, hair style, hair color, and even my face. The graphics seemed to be very simple at first, but as I played the game I understood the deeper meaning as to why the enemies looked like what they did. Although there was no tutorial, the controls were very easy to learn and master. The sounds in this game were definitely very pleasing to listen to. The DLC in this game is an amazing addition to the quality of this masterpiece. The developers of this game are true geniuses for making this beautiful work of art. The only thing that could make this game better is online multiplayer, which I'm absolutely sure many people would enjoy. Although I might consider this a revolutionary free to play game, the highest i can give it is 7.8/10 because it has too much water.

Sakura Clicker is in every form just another clicker game; just like Cookie Clicker, Clicker Heroes, etc.  Just because this clicker game features Anime girls, with big boobs, and moaning sound effects, doesn't really seperate it in anyway from the rest of the genre. You could see these features as the games way to pull you in, just like a good opening paragraph.   This game is practically endless, but can have a completionist end. To 'complete' Sakura Clicker, you have to basically get every possible spirit upgrade. Spirit upgrades are basically this games way of making you want to play it more. You get spirits by restarting the game. You can only restart after getting a certain way into the game, which is usually inbetween Zone 13 to 20, with 20 being basically the have to restart point early on in the game, because of how long it takes to kill anything. These spirits allow you to buy upgrades (which I am hoping will have a definite end, if not, I will be spending way longer than anticipated playing this time waster of a game), which give you buffs for when you start over, to make you feel overpowered, and progress through the game faster, slowly reaching to the point where you quit last time, and hopefully passing that point.   Now do I like this game? Well yeah, and it's not for any idiotic reason, like enjoying the moaning sounds (I have had the game muted most of the time, so that I can do other stuff while it is left in the background), but it is generally because it is a good time waster. If you see this game as anything but a time waster, then you have generally suprised me.  If I would have to critique the game, I would say that it had a hard time running it along side normal internet activities, without giving my computer lag issues. This isn't necessarily a problem, because I can close the game, and just check on it within however long I chose to leave it dorment in my Steam library. But despite this not really being a problem, I would love an option to get rid of these laggy features (I am guessing the money flying all over the place is the main culprit for lag).  I will recommend this game, because it will continue to fill in the gaps of my bored, shut in life. If you have nothing better to do, get Sakura Clicker, it's not like scrolling down your Facebook newsfeed, or watching dumb Youtube videos, are in anyway better than clicking on big breasted Anime girls.

Homemade Tortilla (for 8 servings)  Prep : 30 mins Cook : 25 mins  Ingredients : - 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour - 3/4 teaspoon salt - 1/4 teaspoon baking powder - 1/4 cup vegetable shortening - 1/2 cup hot water  Directions : 1. Whisk flour, salt, and baking powder together in a large bowl. Add vegetable shortening and work into flour mixture using a pastry cutter until it resembles coarse crumbs. 2. Form a well in the middle of flour mixture and mix in hot water. Work flour and water mixture together with a fork and transfer to a cutting board. 3. Knead until a smooth, soft dough is formed, about 3 minutes. Add more flour if dough is too sticky. 4. Place more flour on cutting board, cover dough with bowl, and let rest for 15 minutes. 5. Cut ball of dough into eight equal parts and cover until needed. 6. Roll out balls of dough either by hand or with a tortilla press. 7. Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place flattened tortilla in skillet and cook until it begins to bubble, about 1 minute. Flip tortilla over and cook for an additional minute. Flip again and cook for 1 more minute. Repeat with remaining dough.

If the initial game wasn't free-to-play, I would have felt cheated. And I am rather glad that what actual purchases you can make appear to be cosmetic and not some pay-to-win scheme. Still, there doesn't seem to be any endgame to strive for. Best case scenario, give it a whirl to kill that little bit of time when your waiting for the pizza to be delivered or other such apppointment. Otherwise, dig for something with a little more depth.

Money automatically picks itself up. Bosses are repetable, and have no reprecussions. New models are put in the further you go, with some randomness to the suits. Lotttssss of noises. Lots of them. Some what slow progression, but is easily able to be completed in the background. There is a lot of different DLC for this game, but they are all suits for your character, not needed to play, just fun to have. The 'reset' gives you tokens to use for meta game, they are overpowered and awesome. The abilities are very useful, but with a large cooldown. There is no reason to level past 600, none. I am currently at the point where I can instantly kill them as they spawn in, so there is alot of noises..... On a side note this clicker is entirely able to be edited with Cheat Engine if you arent patient enough to wait out the actual game .-.

I'll keep this shorter than my other Sakura reviews. This game is basically Cookie Clicker but with cute girls drawn in the same great style as the other Sakura games. You basically just click the girls to damage and defeat them and move on to the next area. You earn gold from defeating them which you use to upgrade your MC [aka the clicker] as well as buy upgrades and party members [which act like Grandma, Cookie Farm, stuff like that] Just like in Cookie Clicker, you'll get to the point where you don't really need to click as much anymore, though you'll still probably need to to complete the boss fights because those are timed. The girls also moan a lot when you hit them, so be wary of your sound volume lol  As for the DLC, it's purely cosmetic. Buy it if you feel like supporting the devs and changing up the look of your MC.  In conclusion, this is a free to play game. So just go and try it. You won't be disappointed, unless you're expecting more than just Cookie Clicker Anime Style.

My personal thoughts on this game: Anime girls. Anime girls. ANIME GIRLS!!! 10/10 IGN. Let's go for a more complete answer maybe? It's a clicker game, and for that, it's a very good one.  Pros: Great music and soundtrack! Good job! Also good voice acting for the moans, but I keep that off because it's too distracting, but that's just me. Anime girls that are mostly naked. Whats not to like? Lots of unlockable upgrades and characters! You will still always have something to upgrade, a new hero to unlock so they can help your character deal more damage. There isn't much to say about this game besides the obvious, so heres a copy pasta   n what way is white knight a dumb insult? What exactly do you mean? It's a term that subverts one of the most prevalent literary themes in the adventure stories and fantasies of our childhood. Was there ever a child who didn't pick up a toy sword and imagine themselves to be the civilized hero protecting the weak from from the forces of evil? This trope is relevant to all of us. These stories made enacting justice an absolute virtue and we grew up imagining ourselves as 'white knights' saving the weak from the uncivil. We lived out these fantasies in our imagination and learned that it felt pleasant to be a purveyor of justice, and some of us started to desire that pleasure too much.  That's a problem because the adult world is too complex for that trope to play out as cleanly as it does in stories. An author gets to tell you who is good, who is oppressed, and who is evil -- and this makes the justice of the hero's actions crystal clear. The author's white knight can commit to their campaign with absolute zealotry and the reader is free to revel in pleasurable justice. However, in real life it is often impossible to say who is good, who is oppressed, and who is evil. This is where the problems begin. Lets say I hold a position that I know is virtuous, and I see someone being oppressed by a person who I know is evil. I step in, fully committed to my attack, because I know that it is appropriate to take pleasure in administrating this justice. But are my acts really justified? Is it right that I derive pleasure from them? The fact is I am only acting on my PERCEPTION of reality. Maybe my perception squares with reality, but maybe it doesn't. There is a huge problem with enacting justice when your view of the situation is distorted. This is the premise of one of the most influential novels of all time, The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha.  Its about an old Spanish man around the year 1600 who is obsessed with romantic novels about knights and chivalry. After much isolated reading he becomes manically deluded and starts to believe that he is a knight and that he must set out to revive chivalry, undo wrongs, and bring justice to the world. In a way, Don Quixote was the world's first otaku (a person obsessed with particular aspects of popular culture to the detriment of their social skills). The story plays him for the fool he is, and we laugh at his unwavering commitment to a deluded sense of justice. He even attempts to rescue maidens who are under no threat, in need of no rescue, and are utterly shocked that he believes he's acting on their behalf.  Don Quixote was a cutting satire of the trope of the romantic and chivalrous knight. The phrase 'white knight' now encapsulates everything Don Quixote had to say about the issue, and calling someone a white knight is the same as calling them a Don Quixote. It is a shorthand way of telling them that the real world is more complex than the delusional fantasy of justice they are committed to.  So 'white knight' is not a 'dumb' insult. It's an insult that draws power from a rich history of romance fantasy literature and one of the most significant satirical novels of all time.

I don't even know where to begin.. Once again, I wish I could leave a mixed review rather than a straight up yes or no.  Now, keep in mind that I am never one to complain when sexy women are involved, quite frankly I quite enjoy it. I am not one of those people to go around whinging about women in video games being un-realistic and objectified.. However, there is a border in which certain things cross where it's no longer a game or something to be played to have fun with, but just to act as free or cheap fapping material.   Sakura Clicker, the latest entry to the Sakura series is disguised as an action packed, fast paced, exciting adventure, click to win game and it's nothing of the sort. You launch the game and it plonks you straight in-front of two beautiful anime girls, one is your character, the other your foe. Click away and of course, the moaning begins.  It saddens me that things like this come out disguised as games, why? Because it proves to everyone whom accuses games to objectify women, to in these cases be completely correct. Not only that, but they are designed to pull you in and keep you addicted.  Mind you, that's not even really my complaint behind it. The mechanic of clicking is not my argument of it not being a game either, I've been wrapped up in playing them many times before and the addictive facor always plays a part in keeping you clicking away. No.. My main points against this is that there is no premise in which this is set upon, there is no story, there is no advancement, you are just given 10 cute monster girls that increase in hit points as you go along and that is literally the entirety of this 'game'. There isn't even a level counter, which I honestly think would have added immensely to the game  All in all, I don't find it very tasteful, but on the premise of just being a clicker, it's as good as they get, especially with the bonus of DLC pretties. Want to have gift wrapping on your cute anime warrior? Go right ahead it's all there!  For the fact that there are so many fapping and one handed jokes, you can do better than this. Do me a favor, open your web browser, find yourself a good hentai website and wank that way. Least you don't have to click on the screen for moaning to be heard.

The game is mostly for the sake of bringing people in with the eye candy. The idle game mechanic gets fairly boring quickly, with barely any alternative things to do than play dress up with what appears to be your female companion (with a very limited dress up mechanic, with the idea of unlocking more outfits by buying them with real money). This is a serious review (I feel I have to say that given how many joke reviews have been posted). Since the game is free, there is no harm in just downloading it and giving it a try yourself...unless you will feel awkward having your Steam friends notice that you've played it. If that's the case, please read on.  The game consists of clicking over and over again on enemies to defeat them. Defeated enemies drop gold which can be used to power up your character or hire assistants (who don't appear on screen) that will damage enemies continuously. You can purchase special moves, and there are various rewards (like a permanent increase in all damage dealt) for reaching certain level milestones for your helpers.  Like most Sakura games, the graphics are gorgeous--though you'll have to forgive the developer for reusing enemy sprites. All of the monsters are actually scantily clad women who moan as you fight them (you can turn the moaning off if you find it embarrassing or distracting). You can change the look of your character, and a variety of DLC packs are available for greater customization.  The reason I don't recommend this game is because it only seems to be fun for the first hour or so. After that the difficulty starts ramping up much faster than the level of your character or helpers leading to grinding and frustration. I would prefer a smoother experience. For me, games like this are only addictive if you can continue to feel a real sense of progression. If that sort of thing doesn't bother you, I'd actually be willing to recommend it.   I wish Steam had a neutral button for reviews.

A game where rich, masochistic, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gijinka lesbians pay you and a team of other cute mercenaries in gold coins to hit them. They really know how to make it hail.  While I admit I had fun for the first hour or so of playing this, like any clicker game the novelty wears off fast if you don't keep giving an incentive for the player to WANT to continue. What made Cookie Clicker so great was the funny messages of how your bakery was utterly destroying the universe as well the grand finale of setting off the Grandmapocalypse. Once you reset Haru the first time, it's just the same game starting all over again with maybe a small power-up or two.  Overall,  • Really repetitive gameplay, even for a clicker game.  • One song for the entire game, it doesn't even change for each themed Zone. Lazy.  • Not enough hair colors and eye colors for your custom girl.  • The DLC is, as others have mention, is nothing more than putting clothes on a dollmaker. Not worth $0.99 per article.  • It would be more fun to have clothes that cost in-game currency than actual currency.  • Once you hit the 100aa's the game will start to lose its charm entirely and just turns into a grind or a waiting game.  Maybe someday Sakura Dollmaker could be a thing, but knowing Winged Cloud all they ever want to make is ecchi games that take themselves too seriously. To the point of being cringeworthy.  Also why are there shirts?? Why would you want a shirt of this game? Why does a shirt with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ anime girls come in female sizes? I wouldn't even buy one for a bachelorette party joke gift, there are funnier Engrish shirts that would make better gifts. Greedy, greedy Winged Cloud.
